question: What form of energy causes igneous rock to change into metamorphic rock?

content.source_1: Contact metamorphism occurs when hot magma intrudes and “bakes” adjacent rock; the added heat causes minerals to recrystallize without melting, producing metamorphic rock.
content.source_2: Thermal energy is the energy associated with temperature; heat is the transfer of thermal energy into or out of a material.
content.source_3: Elevated temperature is a principal driver of metamorphism, enabling recrystallization and new mineral growth in rocks.
content.source_4: Dynamic (cataclastic) metamorphism develops in fault zones where intense differential stress and shear dominate, often at relatively low temperatures compared with regional metamorphism.
content.source_5: Mechanical work done by forces during deformation transfers mechanical energy into materials, altering their structure and texture.
content.source_6: Igneous rocks caught in major shear zones can be transformed into mylonites or cataclasites through predominantly mechanical deformation under high stress.
